content: Forward Contracts lock in exchange rates and protect you against volatility in foreign currency markets. This allows you to fix exchange rates for the purchase of currency at a future date, or over a range of dates, up to 12 months into the future. A margin deposit may be required, depending on many factors including credit risk of your company, currency pair involved, maturity of contract, and market volatility.

The agreed upon forward rate in foreign exchange contracts is usually linked to interest rate differentials between the currencies involved. The so-called Forward curve (which is expectation of a future Forward rate for different tenors) can be upward or downward sloping. For example, there are cases where the 12-month forward rate would be better than the current spot rate (this would mean benefit) and there are cases where the 12-month forward rate would be worse (this would mean cost).

A Forward contract is a simple hedging instrument that could be suited when there is a certainty about the date and amounts of future expected payments, or receivables in foreign currency. The Forward contract can be entered into without any up-front costs (margin deposits may apply). The disadvantage of FX Forward is potential opportunity cost in case of a favourable movement in the currency pair in the future.
